item.description:
Object: Players to move around the gameboard with Peter, share his adventures and be the first to finish.

Parts: Game board, spinner, movers with genuine plastic bases, balloon cards

Whether published as Froggy Boogie or Kitty Bitty or some other name, the setting and gameplay of this design remain the same: It's nap time, but the baby critters just want to play. Your job is to make it happen, helping the critters move around without being seen by the adults. Players need to remember which adults are looking in which directions in order to avoid their stares and keep moving!

item.description: For Ages 8 and up. A trivia game with a colorful twist. Every answer is a color.

For children Ages 3 - 5 .

Spin the spinner and when it stops on a color, race to be the first player to move to an object of the same color.

From the Great American Puzzle Factory catalog:

The waddling walking memory matching game! Wiggle, waddle and walk like a penguin from ice float to ice float. Try and collect a matching family of penguins, Dad, Mom, and Baby to win the game - but watch out for the nasty Leopard Seal! An action game that creates lots of laughs.

Ages 4 and up.

From the manufacturer:

The Very Jelly Belly Game is a deliciously fun game for children ages 4 and older. Players use the Jelly Belly character spinner to collect Jelly Belly cards in an attempt to be the first to fill their own collection board with beans of the same color. If they do, they win! It includes 4 Jelly Belly collecting boards, 20 big bean cards, 56 small bean cards and the Jelly belly Spinner.

For Ages 4 and up

Each player is assigned an animal. Then, each player takes a turn to lay down cards. When matching cards are played, make either your own animal noise (young children) or that of an opponent (older children). Contains 6 animal cards and 48 game cards. Different sets of rules for age appropriate play.

name.value: Garfield Pizza Pie and Hairballs Game

item.description:
From the Great American Puzzle Factory product catalog:

Players collect sets of four silly card slices to create an entire pizza of points, while avoiding hairballs other players are throwing their way!

Ages 4 and up

The newest game in Winning Moves Deutschland's series of small square boxes (Spielvergnügen im Quadrat).

Each player has a similar deck of 10 tasks but only two cards are in hand at a time. Each player also has up to six merchants (depending on the number of players) of different height and with different numbers on them, which are distributed over the islands and seas of Zanzibar. After the inital set-up, the players draw their two hand cards, and have to fulfill the tasks on these (either to occupy as many spaces in a certain area as possible or as many places with a certain spice scattered all over the island).

The merchants have different characteristics. For example, smaller ones are faster but the larger ones are stronger, so they can displace them. Points are gained by fulfilling tasks. The better you fulfill the task, the more points you get. But you also have to decide, wether to reject a task or score quickly, even if you get negative score, just to get a better task and force the game to its end. Each player must also reject one or two tasks (depending on the number of players) during the game.

The game ends when one player has fulfilled 9 (or 8 with 4 or 5 players) of his tasks. The player with most points wins.

item.description:
Blurb from the publisher:

"In Grateful Dead™ The Game, players travel through time with the Grateful Dead, collecting concert tickets along the way by answering both interactive and trivia-oriented questions. The team that collects the most tickets wins.

Name the next lyrics to a song, get your teammates to guess which song you are humming or name where the Dead played their only New Year's Eve concert outside the San Francisco Bay area. Each will win your team a ticket. And when you land on or spin “I Need a Miracle Ticket,” it’s time to wager just how much you know!

Packed with art and imagery of the Grateful Dead and the times they defined, this game takes players on a multi-sensory trip with the Dead, celebrating their music and history.

Game comes with game board, spinner, 4 dancing skeleton game pieces, over 900 questions about the Dead, 100 concert tickets and instructions. For 2 or more Adult players."

From the "Are You Game" website:

"Moooo, Oink-Oink, Quack-Quack, Gobble-Gobble! Spend a fun-filled day on the farm as you race to see who can move their farm animals across the board fastest. Spin the spinner, make your animal's sound as you move, but careful where you land - you'll go back to start if you end up on the wrong color. Gobble, Gobble! is a simple-to-learn game that introduces children to decision-making and strategy. Includes 4 each: turkey, pig, duck, and cow playing pieces, 4 color cards, 1 spinner, game board, and instructions. No reading required, great fun for 2 to 4 players Ages 3 to 8."

This is a trivia game with a horse-racing theme. It's complete title is "I.Q. Derby - "It's Official"" There are six categories and the box encourages you to "Get In The Saddle And Test Your I.Q.!" with "The fastest general trivia game around!"

I honestly know little more about the game, as the box is very uninformative and the only copy I have is still in the shrink wrap. I could find no other copies, nor any mention of the manufacturer on the internet. it was made by "KAGE/GAINER INTL., ft. Thomas, Ky. 41075."

The game is in 6 parts, and in the beginning of each part new cards will be added (in the card squares). On the map there is three lines with points, each line representing one of apostle Paul's journeys. The first goes from Antiochia over Minor Asia to Troas, second from Damascus over Athen and back to Sidon, and the third from Tyros over the sea to Rome. The 6 cardsquares are located to Damascus, Antiochia, Jerusalem, Efesos, Malta and Rome.

C.S.A. is a simulation game of the American Civil war. The USA player controls the Union side and the CSA player controls the Confederate side. The Game contains the rulebook, 288 counters, one color map and 10 sheets of charts and tables.

The game uses Ben Madison and Wes Erni's "Charles S. Roberts Award" winning Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918 system to simulate the American Civil War. Units represent Generals (their component brigades are represented off-map), elite units (Iron Brigade, Cobb's Legion), cavalry (Stuart, Stoneman), guerillas (Quantrill, Kirk), and Indians (Choctaws, Delawares, Stand Watie). Like Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918 random events and "Special Event Coins" are crucial, and there are about 400 (yes, 400) of them.

Forming stacks into 'Grand Armies' (e.g. Army of the Potomac, Army of Northern Virginia) enables the various commanders in the stack to coordinate their fighting powers. Cavalry have special abilities but also a habit of running away when you need them. Guerillas ravage the countryside (Quantrill, Price, Morgan -- and the less widely known Union barbarian, George Kirk). Generals do not always follow orders to move, and sometimes must be prodded by expending irreplaceable command chits. Special rules cover foreign intervention, the border states, as well as McClellan, Lee, Jackson and a few other characters. Naval warfare (Confederate commerce raiding) is handled by an extremely simple, elegant abstract model complete with a world map.

The game is won by either capturing the government marker of either player or destroying his economy. Capturing cities and winning naval battles increases the enemy's inflation rate, which affects a lot of elements like national elections (there are three over the course of the game--one in the Confederacy!) and reinforcement rates.

item.description:
"In the Spiderman game you are Spiderman. Each player has his own Spiderman adventure, and the first to finish their adventure and beat the Green Goblin wins."

The game is divided into 4 stages. Each stage is managed by a set of cards:

On chapter 1 you collect 3 power points by traveling on the board. 
Chapter 2 is dexterity test, either using the Spiderman swinger to knock 4 baddies or the maze connecting 5 entries.
Chapter 3, Spiderman recovers from wounds, by collecting both power and knowledge points.
Chapter 4, players have a showdown with the Goblin.

Players progress from one stage to the next as soon as they are ready.

Movement is with dice and spinner.
A mix of luck and dexterity game for Spiderman's fans.

Drinking. History. Violence. The wax museum bar brawl league heats up as new challengers enter the fray. Round 2 includes Atomic Emancipator and Helen Killer, and can be combined with DHV Round 1 to support up to 4 players.

As the attacker, play attacks, struggles, or booze, and the defender plays defends, struggles, or boozes.

Alternate cards until one player chooses to pass, wherein all the cards are resolved in reverse order.

Some cards will be blocked, some cards will be enhanced or reduced based on what was played, and many cards will deal damage to the opponent.

Refill your hand, reverse roles, and continue until sober.

Available from RobotMartini.com.

Combines with:

 DHV Round 1

There is only one right way to make a Long Island Iced Tea! Your way. You don't have all the ingredients to fill your recipes, so you'll have to trade with your fellow bartenders to get everything you need and mix the best Long Island.

Each player has three pieces of Flair. On your turn, you reveal a piece of your hidden recipe, and offer up a Flair card for bid. The other players bid ingredients that they'll give you in exchange for the Flair. You then choose one of the bids that gives you ingredients towards filling your recipe.

Available from RobotMartini.com.
Author and evangelist Ray Comfort and actor Kirk Cameron created this game that promotes the case for intelligent design.

item.description:
This is the younger brother of the very successful Ubongo. 
Besides the fact that it's smaller and that there are new tasks, the characteristics of the game remain the same:

Fast and simple: Fast, because all players play at the same time. Simple, because the rules are easy to grasp.
Who can first find the correct place to put the tiles? Who is then able to place the given figure correctly and in the fastest time?

The game offers two difficulty stages which are fun for beginners and professionals.

item.description:
"Without teamwork, you will never survive. Without betrayal, you’ll never win."

Cutthroat Caverns is played over 9 rounds, each with a random encounter. Essentially a game of 'kill stealing'. Each round, any monster encountered will have a prestige value of 1 through 6. The player that successfully jockeys for position and lands the killing blow gets the prestige value for the encounter. Some encounters will not have a specific monster, such as a trap room for the heroes to pass through (and in this case, earning no prestige). The surviving player with the most prestige after the 9 encounters is the winner. If the players do not survive all 9 encounters, no one wins the game.

A unique combination of cooperative game play and opportunistic backstabbing.

link.value: Cutthroat Caverns Adventures: B1 – Savage Arena / B2 – Errand of Evil
Cutthroat Caverns: Hex Room Promo Card

name.value: Pursuit: A game about the history of civil rights since 1954

item.description:
Publisher:
"Six players, each representing a young black person, compete. (The part of a player may also be taken by a team of two or three players.) The game is played on a board showing a map of the 48 contiguous states. The map contains a red track, a blue one and a green one. As the players move around the tracks, their purpose is to achieve the highest possible goals in five areas: education, housing, jobs, public accommodations and voting. Final score for each player depends on: (1) the goals he set for himself at the beginning; (2) his ability to achieve those goals; (3) the region of the country in which he is located; (4) the time at which he tries to achieve his goals; and (5) a certain amount of luck."

Test your memory with Spider-Man & Friends! Just turn over the cups to see if you can make a match of Spider-Man or his superhero pals!

A version of 'Memory' notably different in that it contains no cards and players are not matching 'identical' pieces; instead, players match the top half of a painted miniature to the bottom half, all hidden under plastic cups. The game comes with a fold-out showing what the complete miniatures look like (mostly unnecessary once you discover, for instance, that Spider-man has bulbous 'manly' feet, and Spider-girl has petite 'girly' feet).

The 'carrying case', when opened, serves as the game board, impressed with spaces to place the half-miniatures and cups.

The rules also list a 'more challenging game' variation: after a 'full' miniature is found it is still removed, but the now empty cups remain on the board to throw off players: this variation is dependent on the plastic cups and therefore unplayable with other Memory-type games that use only cards.

item.description: This is an updated and adjusted version of Diamon Hunt (Jakten på den forsvunnede diamant) and rethemed to fit Norway's only world wide movie success; Flåklypa Grand Prix.
Windsor made this "Shooting" game in 1930. It featured a toy gun with a cork "bullet" which was used to shoot down Pirates in sort of an arcade type game.

Place the game on a table. Players stand 8 to 10 feet away and pitch disks at the gameboard. If any disks lie inside any target circle so as not to touch any part of an edge entitles the thrower to a ticket for that show or thing. The player securing the most tickets at the end of the game wins.

Das Spiele-Buch by Erwin Glonnegger is a comprehensive look at boardgames over the ages. 
It is a German language book filled with illustrations, photos and (if public domain) rules from all aspects of tabletop gaming. Even the glossary and index is dotted with pictures.
It gives descriptions for hundreds of games, sorted by play types, making this book a family reference book on gaming.

A "3D" board game distributed in a bag with jelly beans for fuel. Promotional item for the Disney/Pixar film, "Cars", with two circular tracks linked with a flyover section of track to permit moving from the outer to the inner track. Movement is determined by an ineffectual 6 sided spinner rather than a dice. Cards are randomly placed on the spaces and turned over when the player lands on them. Players must collect 6 "organic fuel" cards to progress to the inner track. "Every time you get an organic fuel card you also get a high octane jelly."

"Shake, Rattle & Score Game
Nine cubes... five have a bead inside--but which ones? Take turns as you each try to pick just the ones with a bead. The more you risk, the more you score--so will you quit after one... or two.. or push your luck and Shoot the Moon?"

A small portable game, consisting of 9 dice within a plastic frame (which keeps them together).
Each dice has one side marked with a color. The one black has a bead inside and one each of the other colored die pairs.
Score based on the number of dice you can select that have beads inside. A push-your-luck mechanic ensures you score 0 if you select wrong.

item.description:
Trio actually comes with two sets of rules.
It uses a custom set of player cards labeled with RUN, SET, RUN/SET, AP, TRIO and valued from 1 through 9.
The object is to score 30 points by discarding runs, sets, pairs and other combinations to the discard pile.

The second game plays 2-6 players, who try to be the first to collect the right cards to match any three of the four control cards dealt to each player at the beginning of the game.

An updated version of Scene it?'s 007 game packaged in a collectible tin. This edition includes new questions and puzzlers from Casino Royale. Includes Cartamundi Playing cards featuring images from 20 Bond movies and 6 new collectible metal tokens. This edition also adds additional Casino Style playing rules on the DVD.

From the publisher:

A must have for the true Bond aficionado, this Collector's Limited Edition of Scene It? James Bond comes in a distinctive tin box and includes a Certificate of Authenticity and exclusive James Bond Playing Cards, featuring images from over 20 Bond films.

This is a Chilean trivia game from 1987. Comes with 6 books of question with the following categories:

 Sports/Recreation
 Natural Science
 Social Science
 TV/Movies/Show Business
 Art
 Trivia




You roll the dice and move in a circular board. The square you are in determines the category. To choose the question you have to roll 3 dice in order, so if for example you rolled a 5 then a 2 and finally a 3, then you have to answer question number 523.
Each number of question comes with 2 questions actually, one more difficult than the other, so the game can be played by parents and children.
The first player to answer correctly one answer of each category when standing in a star square wins the game.

name.value: Life on the Farm: Preschool Edition
Life On The Farm Pre-School Edition

item.description:
From the publisher:

Preschoolers love the happy animal scenes, deep colors and soft feel of We R FUN’s new preschool edition of “Life on the Farm”. Designed for the Ages 3 - 7 demographic, the soft non-toxic foam playmat (for floor play) is a huge 5-piece puzzle. When assembled, the playmate becomes the gameboard. Match colors to move - land on an animal square and get a matching animal puzzle piece to put into a soft barn puzzle. Fill the barn with animals to win. This game quickly became a favorite when tested by early education specialists.

A magazine game from Jeux et StratÃ©gie #60.

Stratego-like game in the context of a rivalry between two little villages. The loser must organize the pétanque competition !

name.value: The Worst-Case Scenario Card Game: Cooking

item.description:
The Worst-Case Scenario card Game - Cooking

Back of the Box:
Boost your kitchen savvy. Learn to survive culinary catastrophes - from opening a bottle of wine without a corkscrew to fixing an over-salted soup. Whether it's dinner for 10 or a meal on the go - you'll be prepared to handle any cooking crisis.

Contents
55 Cards with 108 Questions

Object of the Game
Be the first to consecutively survive 5 scenarios

Players take turns to ask each other the questions on the cards: a correct answer means that they continue asking, wrong means that they pass the questions to the player who was answering who then proceeds.

name.value: Molly's Mystery Party Game A Spy on the Home Front

item.description:
From the box: Solve a mystery with Molly. It's Halloween night - but something mysterious has happened to the candy Molly and her friends collected! Everyone seems to have a motive, so everyone's a suspect. It's up to you and your friends to find the clues, crack the secret code, and unscramble the mystery!

How the Game Works: The mystery features characters from the popular Molly stories. The invitations you send out will tell your friends which character they'll play. On the party day, you and your guests can dress up and "get in character". Together, you'll read the script, search for clues - and solve the mystery!

Home Page: http://www.pleasantcopublications.com/characters/molly/SpyOnTheHomeFront.aspx

For children Ages 4 - 8.

A great game for little folks! Loads of fun trying to make the biggest, daffiest, silliest sandwich of all! [from box]

Roll the dice and move around the board. When you land on a picture of the refrigerator, choose a food item to add to your sandwich. If a player lands on a puppy or kitty square, an ingredient is lost.

item.description:
From the Ravensburger Catalog:

The bears love to play hide and seek! Roll the colored die, move along the path, and hide your three bears first to win. A sliding panel reveals caves for the bears to disappear into as their laughter sounds from a hidden voice chip!

Involves color recognition, association, simple strategy.

Ages 4 and up.

From the Educational Insights catalog:

Panda-Go-Round is a fast paced race game of "turn and find," where each turn of the tube reveals a new expression on the panda's face, from happy or sad to sleepy - even surprised! Be the first to exactly match the expression on the panda's face with the one on the card and claim the card. Corresponding symbols on the tubes and inside the cards make the game self-checking. The player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner. Builds visual discrimination skills, a key to reading success. Includes 2 face-maker tubes and 16 cards.

Ages 4 and up.

From the back of the box:

Here's a game that will have you walking, jumping, and hopping all around the house! Ask a player to give you a card with a specific number of steps to take. Then choose an object that you think you can reach in exactly that number. Can you walk to the fridge in 9 steps? How about hop to something that starts with the letter A in 15? Reach your goal and walk away with a win!

Ages 5 and up.

Kids learn estimating distance and spacial relations.

name.value: Lock 'n Load: Heroes of the Blitzkrieg

item.description:
Heroes of the Blitzkrieg relives the desperate struggle for France in May 1940. Play as the Germans, French, and Belgians. Employ cavalry, Char B1 tanks, Germans Panzers, and much more as you re-fight the German invasion of France.

6 geomorphic maps plus a sheet of overlays.
Over 420 counters, representing the men and equipment
16 scenarios
16 New Skill Cards, providing Leaders and Heroes with special abilities.
Complete V3 LnL Rules, plus the Heroes of the Blitzkrieg specific rules. 
Player's aid charts. dice, and box.

This game is no longer available and can be found in Lock 'n Load Tactical: Heroes in Defiance

link.value: Lock 'n Load Tactical: Days of Villainy
Lock 'n Load Tactical: World War II Era Core Rules Manual v4.1

item.description:
THE CRISIS:
A world famous physicist, noted for discovering a new fuel source, has been kidnapped and is being held hostage in a remote jungle fortress somewhere near the equator. Intelligence sources believe the physicist will reveal the new fuel source to whomever liberates him.

THE MISSION:
As Chief of Intelligence for a world superpower, you control the movements of a special secret agent/army commando rescue team in a daring plot to liberate the physicist and return him to your home embassy. You must outwit and outmaneuver each of your opponents if your mission is to succeed. Careful planning is crucial to avoid setbacks along the way. A word of advice: keep your team together and above all, watch your back!

February of 1994. The Argentine military retakes power through a coup de etat. The Argentine civil government manages to find exile in neighboring Uruguay. The Argentine military issues an ultimatum to Uruguay to hand over the fugitives or face an invasion. Brazil guarantees the defense of Uruguay in the event of a Argentine invasion. Argentina launches a surprise invasion of Uruguay precipitating a counter attack from the Brazilians thus starting the war of the Pampas.

The war of the Pampas is a Brazilian designed Alternate history wargame of a war between Argentina vs. Uruguay and Brazil in an alternate early 90s.

The game consists of 169 counters representing the military forces of Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. 12 pages of rules. and special rules such as artillery, air support and more...

Game comes with a rule sheet and 60 cards. This is an inexpensive and pocketable little word building game that actually has strategy considerations. When to play a single letter card, when to play a "combo" card, when to sweep the table? Wow! This is Combo. For 2 to 5 teens & adults

From Playroom Catalog:

Be the first to reach the Temple of the Monkey in this Action packed card game of jungle adventure! Each player takes on the role of a daring explorer racing along a unique path to the temple, battling raging rapids, dangerous predators, and most importantly, each other! Every step along the path comes with its own challenges, and explorers must be prepared for whatever comes their way.

Players must travel down their own set of path cards, representing the obstacles standing between them and the Temple. Use your equipment cards to overcome the hurdles in your path, and your tactics to foul up your opponents efforts, but most of all, use your wits as you race to the Temple of the Monkey!

link.value: The Princess Bride: Storming the Castle

item.description:
First to Fight is a simulation game on the German blitzkrieg invasion of Poland in September 1939, the event that ignited World War II in Europe.

First to Fight is a two player game, with one player representing the German high command and the other the Polish high command. The German player must crush Poland in a lighning campaign. Speed is essential - the outcome must be settled quickly in order to shift troops west in time to forestall or defeat a French offensive on Germany's western border. The Polish player must successfully defend Poland or, failing in this, at least hold out long enough to disrupt the German timetable for conquest. Both sides maneuver their forces and conduct combat in an attempt to achieve these goals.

Game Scales:

 Time: Three Day Turns
 Map: 16 Miles Per Hex
 Unit: Divisions, Regiments & Battalions





First edition Components (1991):

 Countersheets 18A, 19A, 57 & ACS 
 Two Maps (Europa Maps 13A & 37)
 Rules Book
 OB Book
 Chart Set
 Two Six-Sided Dice




Second edition Components (1999):

 Countersheets CS 18B, 19B, 57A, 57A-1 & ACS-2 (1296 Counters)
 Two Maps (Europa Maps 13A & 37)
 rules (dated 1998) - 32 pages
 orders of battle (dated 1997) - 28 pages
 7 charts "First to Fight" & 4 charts "Grand Europa"




A refit kit was also published in 1999 to upgrade rules and counters.
It includes most second edition components: 

 rules (dated 1998) - 32 pages
 orders of battle (dated 1997) - 28 pages
 revision guide (dated 1998) - explains how to update 1991 rules with 1997 counters - 3 pages
 7 charts "First to Fight" & 4 charts "Grand Europa"
 4 countersheets: CS 18B, CS 19B, CS 57A and CS57A-1 (dated 1997)

item.description:
Players roll the dice and completes a driving test in order to move their token through the driving circuit.

Contains a road safety message from Jack Brabham.

Produced by "Ampol - The Australian Company".

name.value: Principles of War: 19th Century – Army Lists for Africa, India, Asia, the Far East, the Americas and post World War One

item.description:
[From the inside cover]
These lists are designed to cover warfare around the world from the Napoleonic Wars until the opening of the First World War, with some lists to cover the chaotic period after the war including the Russian Revolution.

Within each list, the armies have been sorted by conflict with participants where possible listed together. You will note that each army list has a points value listed against it, all armies do not have the same points values, this is because some conflicts were smaller than others and we did not wish to artificially inflate army sizes just to get a standard points value.

Deluxe Weed! is a strategy card game where players compete to grow the most pot plants. Includes all the same cards as the original Weed! card game and 7 new characters! You can still Steal plants from other players and Bust another player for possession. Now you can also use Wendy Weedwacker to slowly hack away at someone's garden. Bugs eat away at a plant card unless you stop them with a can of Bug Spray. POTZILLA still wipes out a player's entire garden, but you can now annihilate everyone's crops with Slash Burn.

item.description:
This cardgame is a multi-player solitaire. The deck consists of 96 cards (hence the name), 6 of each in the numbers 1 through 16. You can be as many players as you like, but each players will need his own deck.

One player shuffles his deck and draws the cards, one by one, telling the others what he drew, so all players will get their cards out in the same order (similar mechanic to Take it Easy).

The point is to build stacks of cards going from 1 to 16. When the last card is drawn points are awarded for how many complete stacks you've managed to build.

name.value: Dick Tracy The Master Detective Game

item.description:
A simple children's race game which takes place on a bright yellow street map of the town. The board and its spaces are illustrated with characters from the Dick Tracy comic strip. Based on the famous character from cartoons and television shows.

Components include a gameboard; 5 pawns (4 Deputies, 1 Villain); 28 loot cards (4 ea. Blank; Drug; Apparel; Fur; Jewelry; Bond; Cash); Spinner.

The players are drawing subject cards and rolling letter dice. Ie. the subjects could be Capitols, animals, female artists, mountains and cold drinks, and the letters could be A, E, G, H and P. 
Then the players will write down answers that matches these subjects and letters, receiving points for the answers given. More points are scored for answers you are the only one having.

The object of the game is to build a rocket made up of four sections, and then navigate it through space following a set flight plan that is drawn at the start of the game.

As you explore each new star system, a section of your rocket is jettisoned and the rocket accelerates until it reaches maximum speed and heads for your home system. The first player to complete their flight plan wins the game.

Game Contents:

• 1 Large playing board divided into two main sections depicting a rocket gantry for the preparation of the rocket and a star map for traveling through space.

• 6 Counters in six different colors

• 6 Rockets in six different colors, each rocket is made up of four sections.

• 6 Flight Plans

• 24 Flight Check Cards

• 1 Die

• 1 Dice cup

• 1 Rules booklet

Bendominoes play like regular dominoes, but each piece is curved, which offers different challenges and ways to control the game.

Ages 5 and up.

item.description: A version of Bendomino for Ages 3 and up, where you match pictures instead of dots. Game comes with 28 wooden Bendominoes and a cotton pouch.

The object of the game is to be the player to have the most points when the game ends. (Copied from the game's instructions)
Players roll a die and move their token first to complete the 'car' track, then to use their boats to move to different islands. Different spaces will allow players to draw a card from the elephant deck. Alternatively players may visit shops to collect souvenir cards. When a player reaches the end of the track the game ends.

name.value: Trivial Pursuit: Edition Music 1990 à maintenant – Jeu compact

item.description:
From the back of the box:

Test your knowledge of the '90s onwards. For hardcore music buffs, there are essential facts related to music, concerts and videos. For the more lifestyle conscious, there's must-have info on the celebrities that make the music - their sense of fun, their love-lives, famous interview quotes and lots more.

Whatever your interest, it's all here in this handy wedge that you can take anywhere. Or, if you prefer, you can use these 600 questions with your Trivial Pursuit boardgame.


This is another in the "Bite-Size" range of Trivial Pursuit games. It is intended as a portable travel game. The game is packaged in a wedge ("piece-of-pie") shaped box.

The game does not feature a game board, and thus, there is no roll-and-move mechanic. Instead, players roll the color-coded die, and answers a question matching the color rolled. If a player correctly answers a question, he may "go for a wedge" by answering another question in the same category. If he does so, he keeps that card. If the player answers a question incorrectly, it is the next player's turn. Play ends when a player has collected six cards/correctly answered 12 questions.

Oware is one of the most played games in the Kalah Family of pit and pebbles games. It is the National game of Ghana and the word "oware" means "He She Marries". The mythology behind the name is believed by many to be the result of a wedding between a man and a woman and the dowry (represented by fields (pits) and seeds. Basically, you're playing for fruitful paddocks.

The game as played in Ghana is a social event and is commonly played on the street. Heckling, banging the fist and mocking are all allowed. The game is also used in education among the Asanti children for the development of maths skills.

Most of the oware available in Ghana is hand carved and comes with traditional symbols of the Asanti people carved into the wood. The traditional playing seeds are Bonduc seeds, a bright green seed with a hard shell. Stones and sometimes recycled glass are used.

As for the other games in the Mancala Family, the rules differ from country to country; however, for Oware there is an international organization which sets the standard.

The basic object of the game is to capture more seeds than your opponent. This is done by landing the last seed you are "sowing" in a pit on the opponent's side which already contains one or two seeds. Other rules allow multiple captures and the avoidance of "stalemates".

item.description:
K Cricket consists of 50 cards: 17 Bowling cards and 33 Batting cards, each showing a particular type of delivery e.g. Good Length, Bouncer, Cut, Hook. Play consists of the bowling player playing a card and the batting player trying to match it with a scoring or defensive stroke. If the batting player has only a dismissal to match the ball bowled, he must play it and his batsman is out.

The game is played in six-ball overs, the bowling player drawing a new hand after each over while the batting player continues with the hand they were initially dealt but draws to refill his hand after each ball bowled.

Players can play an agreed number of overs or a full 10-wicket innings each.

Binary is a series of 4 games that use a unique deck of cards. One side of the deck is all black the other side is all white.
The games require a basic knowledge of binary numbers, which the rules provide.

Binary I - a basic game of each player dealing out 4 cards and the highest number takes the pot. (an introduction into binary numbers)

Binary II - similar to Binary I, but players lay the 4 cards one at a time.

Binary III - similar to Binary II, but players lay the 4 cards one at a time, allowing players to raise if they believe they will have the highest number

Binary IV - players across from the table play with the same 4 cards to change it into the highest number. Each plays from their own perspective.

With just 5 pieces each and 3 rules governing their placement, this game reflects the simplicity of the art and architecture movement which it is named after. The wooden blocks represent 'Bauhaus' style buildings which are placed on to the board. Following the 3 rules of placement, the player who is the last one able to go is the winner.
A typical Niek Neuwahl game of elegant simplicity and strategy.

item.description:
From the press release:

The Gut-Busting Game that’s a Blast! Gassy Gus is the hilarious game that’s a blast for all ages! Players use cards to “feed” Gus all sorts of gaseous foods – from broccoli to baked beans. With each tasty dish players must pump up Gus and watch his belly grow bigger and bigger. Watch out for the big blast of “gas”! You never know when Gus will have a blow-out and give you a stinky penalty. Be the first to feed Gus all your food and win!

Match Up Your Friends. Then send them on their first dates, in hopes of love at first sight. But be careful, other matchmakers will be trying to steal them out from under your nose.

This is a fast party game for up to 8 people.

item.description:
Dear Judge Ichiro: the Board Game’ is a group game for 3 or more players derived from the novel Dear Judge Ichiro by Trevor Ryan (Zeus Publications). 
It is based on problem solving, specifically anagrams, listening comprehension, parables, and proverbs.

Home Page: http://www.geocities.com/kevinbonbevan/index.htm

This is a party game, along the lines of Cranium, but all about the movies.
The production values are very high, and there are more than 1300 cards, each with four questions/activities on them, making it pretty re-playable.
The cards are split onto 4 eras - The Studio Years (1927 to '49), The Independent Years (1950 to '69), The Corporate Years (1970 to '89) and The Blockbuster Years (1990 to 2006), and each team only has to complete two eras, so the game can be played with different age groups.
There are 6 different activities on the cards:
Cutting Room (A pot-potpourri of quotes, quips and quirky facts from both on- and off-screen)
Rushes (The players are the stars as they re-create famous scenes from favorite films)
Soundtrack (Hum, whistle, pound the piano or use the Cinematique kazoos to perform film songs)
Casting (Questions about famous roles, fabulous pairings and the actors who created them)
Screen Test (Mime classic scenes, impersonate the stars or be a legend of the silver screen)
Credits (An optional activity and something for the film buffs - hard, but rewarding)
Minis-rules for 1600-1870. Skirmish level, up to about 40 men per player. Free download.

Publisher:
"The object of the game is to be the first player to go from elementary school through college while answering inference questions."

Australian Trivia Game

Over 2000 Questions in the following catagories:

People
Places
Slang
Sport
Animals & Plants
History

And the wacky activity "Up The Creek" category.

Packaged in an Australian esky!

Racing is, of course, a racing game. Place the cars on the start line, roll the die and be first to the finish line. If you land on a square with star, you draw an event card which lets you advance some spaces, miss a turn, move again or similar. 
Other squares have text that tells what happens when you land on them, for instance: "You drive perfectly through the first curve. You get an extra die roll" and 
"Trouble with the engine. Move 10 squares backwards".

First car to the finish line wins the game

In Bummer, players use 5 dice to try to score points. They set aside scoring dice and may continue with the rest.

Bummer predates Farkle and has different scoring methods. Players score on 1s and 5s and also three of a kind, four of a kind and straights in a single roll.

This is an adult-themed game to taste the sexual knowledge of the participants. It is a fast, fun game with mainly esoteric questions; for example: "How many dating agencies were there in Britain at the start of 1994?" and "Who invented the contraceptive pill?". Players attempt to answer questions correctly from 3 possible answers to move around a scoreboard ahead of their opponents.

name.value: Junior Table Top Bowling Alley Game

item.description:
This game features 10 scaled bowling pins, 3 bowling balls, and a real return track, an adjustable spring bowler, scoring pads.

The game also includes an application for a junior bowling league.

From the box cover; "A game of fun and skill for the whole family."

Game features a giant wheel that looks somewhat like a large gambling wheel, and a giant gameboard. Simple game of spin the wheel and move along the gameboard, first to finish wins the game. Ages 6 - 12

Fran Tarkenton's Pro Football was a playable yet highly detailed simulation of pro football in the days before the NFL and AFL consolidated. (Tarkenton was a New York Giant quarterback at the time – before he led the Vikings to three Super Bowls.)

The game was advanced for the time, and very much a simulation. The game used 23 offensive basic plays and 8 defensive lines. Unlike some contemporaries and many lesser football games, the proper defense will limit the damage of a great roll. Despite the limited number of offensive plays, there are plenty of choices since the plays can showcase feature positions. Also, beyond the 8 defensive setups, the defensive player can also have the choice of which player to 'key' on. Of course, double-covering the wrong receiver will allow a lesser roll to have a higher result.

The true advancement for the game system was the yearly 'rating' of each team on their defensive and offensive line in each of these plays. Thus, when you played two teams, there was a die roll modifier for each play based on each defense.

The clock functions were also very good, allowing a true 'two minute drill' and the use of real game strategies.

Fran Tarkenton's Pro Football is a great time capsule with a look at the teams in the 1960s, before they merged to become the NFC and AFC.

link.value: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

item.description: "Enjoy the thrills and skills of football by planning the moves that bring the goals." A very abstract two player simulation of a football match, published sometime in the late Sixties.

4th Street Baseball is a baseball simulation game using individual ratings to recreate big league baseball action. Ratings are printed in booklet format on perforated cardstock. They measure 3.5" x 2.5" (the same size as a bubble-gum card).
 The game starts with the pitcher. Each pitcher is rated for his ability to get the ball over the plate, the likelihood of him giving up the long ball, walk to strikeout ratio, hits allowed, etc.
 Each hitter has been rated for average, extra-base potential, strikeouts and walks, base running, stealing, bunting, and lefty-righty hitting. In addition, pitchers and hitters are rated for defensive range, error frequency, outfielder-catcher arms, and infielders ability to turn the double play.
 Five dice are employed in 4th Street Baseball...one twenty-sided (d20), two ten-sided (d10), and two six-sided (d6). 
 Play starts by determining the count. The two d10 are rolled and the count is determined by looking at the pitcher's count column. If the pitcher gets ahead in the count, his ratings, along with all of the defensive players behind him, increase. If he falls behind, then the increase is instead given to the hitter. The defense is allowed to position its players and selects a strategy card (fastball, breaking ball, pitchout, etc.). The offense, likewise, selects a strategy card (hit and run, steal, etc.). All five dice are rolled, the strategy cards are revealed, and the play continues by finding a "matchup" on the pitcher's card. Matchups vary from balls hit to a specific fielder, to batter-pitcher battles, to ballpark and defensive positioning effects. Once a matchup has been determined, the defender's rating is subtracted from the hitter's rating and the result is compared to the d20. If the result is less than or equal to the d20, the hitter wins the matchup and the final result of the play is read off the hitter by adding the two d6 and referring to the appropriate column. If the d20 result is higher, then the play result is found similarly on the defensive player.

The game comes with a book (or two books, depending upon the season) full of baseball player ratings which are perforated to 2.5" x 3.5" (the same size as a bubble-gum card), baseball fields (printed on 8.5" x 11" card stock, for each team), dice, strategy cards, an easy-to-read results chart, and score sheets. All players are rated for the 2005 season, except those with less than 25 at bats or innings pitched, or pitchers who had 2 or less starts.

The game of Consequences is a fun way to introduce or reinforce the idea that there is a consequence for all actions and behavior. Each card has an everyday task or behavior that results in a forward or backwards move. Roll the Dice to see how many stones you may travel. Follow the colorful stone path to the park, take a ride on the slide, go for ice cream and end at WATERLAND!! Ages 3 and up

Just as honeybees move from flower to flower collecting nectar to create honey, you'll move around the Spelling Beez game board collecting letters to create words. With two levels of play, children of all ages will enjoy this unique and educational spelling game. While younger children work to collect letters that spell simple words, older children are challenged by collecting letters for more difficult words. Older children will also share and learn interesting facts about honeybees as they try to collect the most pollen and nectar points to win the game. Spelling Beez is all you need to learn your ABC's.

Ages 4 -8

Contents: Spelling Beez Game Board; 80 Pollen/Nectar Cards; 60 Spelling Beez Cards; Honeycomb Score Sheets; 4 Worker Bee Playing Pieces; Rules Booklet

A mini-game that comes with the World Works Games cardstock model set "Shellendrak Manor". Players take the role of one of four treasure hunters searching for a lost pendant in the Manor.

Play takes place on the fully-constructed cardstock model. The entire set must be printed on card stock paper and requires construction.

MathAnimals is an exciting game that teaches and reinforces addition, subtraction and multiplication skills for children of all ages. With the roll of a die, players race around the colorful game board trying to land their playing piece on the animal that represents the highest number. Then they either add, subtract or multiply the number on the die to the number they have landed on. The first to reach the "winning goal", a pre-set number that can change with each new game, is the winner! With more than 6 variations of game play, MathAnimals will continue to stimulate learning and grow with your child for years to come. Ages 5 and up

The “What if...” game that could save your child’s life- teaching kids how to avoid abduction and abuse.

The greatest way to reduce children’s fear of abduction and molestation, while at the same time offering them the highest degree of protection, is to give them knowledge of how to respond when faced with a potentially dangerous situation. With a “What if...” game format using question/answer cards, Situations™ teaches children how to recognize and respond when confronted with potentially life threatening scenarios. You and your children will learn many of the actual methods and schemes used by real child predators one may read about in local newspapers.

This game will also have a profound impact on opening the lines of communication between children and their parents with respect to these subjects that, for even the best of parents, are often difficult to discuss.

Situations™ is a must for homes, classrooms, daycares and other group settings. This game is specifically designed for play between one or more children AND a parent or teacher, and is NOT recommended to be played without an adult. 
Ages 4 and up
Rev the bug up and set it in the center of the board. Watch as it spins out into one of the colored holes. That player gets to move his scoring peg.

In and Out is a simple roll and move game based on a swimming "Bath". The edge of the pool is numbered 1 to 54. Ten of the squares are entrances to the pool and when the player lands on them they must roll again and follow the path of a swimmer through the water back to the poolside. The pool sections are similar to the familiar snakes and ladders, with one difference - the paths through the pool are marked out in squares and thus may represent delays as well as the usual short-cuts or backward steps.

The game appears to consist of only the board, counters and a die to be supplied by the player. The instructions mention "dice" but it is likely that the game was intended to be played with one die. Each player must roll "3" to begin and the exact number to finish which might be impossible with a pair of dice.

The board illustration is quite pleasant, possibly representing an Art Deco swimming pool. All the swimmers are male, in red or blue trunks.

Valentine's Games were proud to proclaim the board as "British Manufacture". The game is marked as copyright, but this is undated, although the provenance of the game suggests the game to be no later than 1950. It is marked G12 suggesting that other boards were available from Valentine's Games.

From the back of the box:

"To play the game, suspects (called players) make their getaway beginning and ending at Rockington Estate. Unlucky players will wear the disguise or go to Da Pokey. The lucky player landing on the Outrageous Journalist (sticking his microphone out of a manhole) will collect $10 grand.

"The player collecting the most evidence wins, and in this game evidence can be bought and sold."

This simple and colorful boardgame was meant to satirize the many court trails which fueled a media frenzy in the early nineties.

From the back of the box:

Apples to Apples Jewish Edition brings the award winning card and party game, Apples to Apples, to Jewish Families and friends. Players will delight in the clever comparisons while expanding their knowledge of Jewish themes.

Contains fun, new cards based on Jewish life, history and culture.

Part of the Apples to Apples Series.

item.description: Dai (or great) shogi is one of several large Shogi games that date from the Middle Ages of Japan. It is thought to be a precursor of today's standard shogi game. It is played on a 15×15 board. Each player starts the game with sixty-five pieces of twenty-nine different types. Unlike shogi, dai shogi does not permit "drops".

Roll the dice and move, go from start to finish in the castle. But on the way you can meet a ghost, witch, owl, king or maybe a bat. On the 48 different cards, "mysterious messages", you will get missions to complete.
The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Gloucestershire, in the United Kingdom.

item.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Devon, in the United Kingdom.

Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Hull, in the United Kingdom.
